laws.summary: New Jersey law does not impose a strict statewide ban on asking salary history, but employers are restricted from screening applicants based on wage history and retaliation is prohibited.
requirements: Employers may not screen applicants based on wage history
Employers may not require wage history to meet minimum or maximum criteria
Applicants may voluntarily disclose wage history
Employers may verify wage history only after an offer of employment has been made
Retaliation against applicants who refuse to provide wage history is prohibited
laws.notes: New Jersey’s approach is functionally similar to a salary history ban in practice.

laws.summary: New Jersey enacted a pay transparency law requiring covered employers to include salary or wage ranges in job postings.
laws.statute_citation: New Jersey Pay Transparency Act (P.L.2024, c.7)
requirements: Employers with 10 or more employees must include salary or hourly wage range in job postings
Postings must include a general description of benefits and other compensation
Applies to internal and external job postings
Pay range must be a good-faith estimate
Retaliation against employees for requesting pay information is prohibited
laws.notes: This law aligns New Jersey with states like NY, CA, and MN on pay transparency.

laws.summary: Non-compete agreements are generally enforceable in New Jersey if reasonable, but courts scrutinize them closely.
laws.statute_citation: New Jersey common law (e.g., Solari Industries, Inc. v. Malady)
requirements: Must protect legitimate business interests
Must be reasonable in duration
Must be reasonable in geographic scope
Must not impose undue hardship on the employee
Must not be injurious to the public
Courts may modify or invalidate overly broad restrictions
laws.notes: New Jersey applies a three-part reasonableness test to restrictive covenants.

laws.summary: New Jersey restricts criminal history inquiries under its ban-the-box law and requires FCRA compliance for third-party background checks.
laws.statute_citation: New Jersey Opportunity to Compete Act; Fair Credit Reporting Act (15 U.S.C. § 1681)
requirements: Employers with 15+ employees cannot inquire into criminal history during initial application process
Criminal history inquiries generally permitted only after the first interview
If using a third-party background check, written consent is required
Pre-adverse action notice must be provided with copy of report and rights
Final adverse action notice must be provided if a negative decision is made
laws.notes: Applies to most private employers with 15 or more employees.

laws.summary: New Jersey mandates paid sick leave and has robust family leave protections.
laws.statute_citation: New Jersey Earned Sick Leave Law; New Jersey Family Leave Act (NJFLA)
requirements: Employees accrue up to 40 hours of paid sick leave per year
Accrual generally at 1 hour per 30 hours worked
Leave can be used for illness, preventive care, family care, and domestic violence issues
Employees are entitled to job-protected family leave under NJFLA
Jury duty leave is protected
laws.notes: Offer letters must not conflict with statutory paid sick leave rights.

laws.summary: New Jersey legalizes recreational cannabis and provides strong employment protections for lawful off-duty use.
laws.statute_citation: New Jersey Cannabis Regulatory, Enforcement Assistance, and Marketplace Modernization Act (CREAMMA)
requirements: Employers generally cannot refuse to hire or take adverse action based solely on off-duty cannabis use
Employers may prohibit impairment during working hours
Employers may use drug testing but must comply with statutory requirements
Safety-sensitive exceptions exist
laws.notes: New Jersey has some of the strongest employee cannabis protections in the U.S.

laws.summary: Arbitration agreements are generally enforceable in New Jersey if they meet contract law standards, but certain waivers of statutory rights are restricted.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act; Atalese v. U.S. Legal Services Group
requirements: Arbitration clauses must clearly and unambiguously waive the right to sue in court
Agreements must be voluntary and clearly drafted
Must not be unconscionable
Courts scrutinize arbitration clauses in employment agreements
laws.notes: New Jersey courts require heightened clarity in arbitration clauses.

laws.summary: New Jersey follows the at-will employment doctrine, subject to statutory, contractual, and public policy exceptions.
requirements: Employment is presumed at-will unless contract specifies otherwise
Cannot terminate for discriminatory reasons
Cannot retaliate for protected activity
Public policy exceptions apply
Employee handbooks can create implied contractual obligations unless properly disclaimed
laws.notes: Clear at-will language and handbook disclaimers are important in New Jersey.

laws.summary: New Jersey provides some of the strongest anti-discrimination protections in the United States.
laws.statute_citation: New Jersey Law Against Discrimination (N.J.S.A. 10:5-1 et seq.)
requirements: Cannot discriminate based on race, color, religion, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation
Cannot discriminate based on age, disability, national origin, marital status
Cannot discriminate based on pregnancy, military status, domestic violence victim status
Harassment is prohibited
Retaliation for protected activity is prohibited
laws.notes: NJ LAD is broader than federal law and aggressively enforced.

additional_notes.general_guidance: New Jersey is highly employee-protective, with strong pay transparency rules, ban-the-box protections, paid sick leave, and cannabis employment protections. Offer letters must be carefully drafted for compliance.

New Jersey Division on Civil Rights
